FIRE DEPARTMENT



§ 32.01  ESTABLISHMENT OF THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.



   The Fire Department is hereby established to consist of a Chief and a
sufficient number of fire fighters, volunteer and paid, to maintain and
operate the department.  The department and all members, both volunteer and
paid, shall operate under the general direction of the Chief. The Fire Chief
is appointed by and works under the general direction of the Town Manager.
The Board of Aldermen is responsible for providing funding for the operation
of the Fire Department and payment of all expenses associated therewith and
for establishing policy, procedures and all other matters related to the Fire
Department, which matters shall be implemented through the Town Manager and
subsequently the Fire Chief.



(Ord. 1240, passed 8-25-94)



§ 32.02  FIRE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS.



   (A)   The Fire Department shall consist of both volunteer and paid
members.



   (B)   The Fire Chief shall be responsible for establishing ranks
within the Fire Department. The Chief shall do so in accordance with existing
town ordinances, policies and other applicable federal or state laws and
regulations.  All members of the Fire Department, both paid and volunteer,
shall be eligible to hold rank.



(Ord. 1240, passed 8-25-94)



§ 32.03  DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE FIRE CHIEF.



   The duties and responsibilities of the Fire Chief shall include, but
not necessarily be limited to, the following:



   (A)   Acting as the Chief Executive Officer for the Department and
being held accountable to the Town Manager and Board of Aldermen for the
supervision and oversight of the department.



   (B)   Being held responsible to the Town Manager and Board of
Aldermen for the promulgation of orders, regulations, and policies made or
given by or through the Town Manager relating to the Fire Chief's duties and
those of his department.



   (C)   Conferring with and being advised by the Town Manager on all
important matters not otherwise provided for in the regulations, policies and
ordinances.



   (D)   Performing all duties as required by the North Carolina
General Statutes, the Town Charter, the code of ordinances, and the policies
developed for the Fire Department by the town.



   (E)   Controlling and being responsible for all actions of the Fire
Department and its employees, both full-time and volunteer.



   (F)   Establishing and maintaining policies  for recruitment and
selection of volunteer members of the Fire Department, such policies to be
consistent with existing recruitment policies of the town.



   (G)   Inspecting, on a regular basis, the equipment of the Fire
Department.



   (H)   Supervising the fighting and extinguishing of all fires.



   (I)   Exercising authority at all fire scenes to ensure that fires
are expediently extinguished and that persons inhibiting the fire fighting
function do not interfere.



   (J)   Causing all fire hydrants to be inspected at least once every
six months and report to the Town Manager the results of the inspections.



   (K)   Ensuring that complete and accurate records regarding all
departmental activity are maintained.



   (L)   Assuming the duties of the Fire Prevention Officer.



   (M)   Investigating, or causing the investigation of, all fires
occurring within the town in an effort to ascertain the cause of each fire.



   (N)   Developing and maintaining an appropriate recruitment and
training program for the department.



   (O)   Coordinating the fire inspection program for the town.



   (P)   Serving as emergency preparedness coordinator.



   (Q)   Performing other duties as required. (Ord. 1240, passed
8-25-94)



§ 32.04  CHAIN OF COMMAND.



   (A)   The Fire Chief shall be responsible, subject to the approval
of the Town Manager, for establishing a chain of command for the Fire
Department.



   (B)   All members of the Fire Department, both paid and volunteer,
shall be obligated to comply and act in accordance with the chain of command
for the Fire Department so established by the Fire Chief.



(Ord. 1240, passed 8-25-94)



§ 32.05  FIRE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS SUBJECT TO PERSONNEL ORDINANCES OF THE
TOWN.



   (A)   All paid members of the Fire Department shall be subject to
certain sections of the personnel policies of the town.



   (B)   Volunteer members of the Fire Department shall be subject to
certain sections of the personnel policies, such sections to include the
following:



      (1)   Recruitment policies as set forth in the personnel
policies to include, but not necessarily limited to Equal Opportunity
Employment Policy, Equal Opportunity Employment Responsibility, Recruitment,
Implementation, Recruitment Sources, Job Advertisements, Applications for
Employment, Application File, Selection, Qualifications and  Standards, and
any amendments to or substitutions for these sections.



      (2)   In keeping with the council-manager form of government,
all appointments to the Fire Department, both paid and volunteer, shall be
subject to the final approval of the Town Manager.  Appointments to vacant
positions shall be based upon the recommendations made by the Fire Chief.



      (3)   Promotions policies and any amendments to or
substitutions for this section.



      (4)   The grievance procedures and procedures for disciplinary
action to include but not be limited to oral reprimand, written reprimand,
suspension, demotion, and dismissal as set forth in Chapter 34 of the town
code.



      (5)   The provisions of the personnel policies regarding
personnel records to include Personnel Records Maintenance, Personnel
Records, Basic Information Maintenance, Access to Personnel Records, Former
Employees, Remedies of Employees Objecting to Material in File, Penalty for
Permitting Access to Confidential File by Unauthorized Person, Disposal of
Records Regulated, and Violations, or any amendments to or substitutions for
these sections.



      (6)   Restriction on the use of confidential information or
any amendments to or substitutions for this section.



   (C)   In addition to the provisions of the personnel policies to
which volunteer and paid members of the Fire Department are subject, all
volunteer and paid members of the Fire Department shall be subject to rules
and regulations adopted for the operation of the Fire Department by the Fire
Chief acting under the supervision of the Town Manager.



(Ord. 1240, passed 8-25-94; Am. Ord. 1489, passed 1-12-06)



§ 32.06  RELATIONSHIP OF FIRE DEPARTMENT AND VOLUNTEER MEMBERS.



   (A)   The Board of Aldermen recognizes that historically the
volunteer members of the Fire Department have organized into a group for the
purpose of enhancing their capability as fire fighters and improving fire
suppression services provided to the town. The Board of Aldermen recognizes
the right of the volunteer members to organize into such a volunteer group
known as the "Wrightsville Beach Volunteer Firefighters Association," (herein
"WBVFA") provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed
to authorize any activities which are in violation of the restrictions of
G.S. Ch. 95, Art. 12.



   (B)   (1)   The responsibility for: (a) establishing recruitment
policies for volunteer members; (b) selecting volunteer members consistent
with existing town policies; (c) establishing and maintaining training and
performance standards for volunteer members; (d) terminating participation by
volunteer members in the Fire Department; and (e) managing and supervising
the activities of volunteer members while participating as members of the
Fire Department is given to the Town Manager acting through the Fire Chief.



      (2)   Prior to implementing changes to (a) recruitment and
selection policies of volunteer members or (b) training and performance
standards for volunteer members, the town will use its best efforts to
consult with officers of the WBVFA regarding such matters; provided, however,
that nothing contained herein shall obligate the town to consult with WBVFA,
and the town shall be and remain responsible for all such actions as they
relate to volunteer members of the Fire Department. In the event WBVFA is
dissatisfied with such changes in recruitment and selection policies of
volunteer members or training and performance standards for volunteer
members, it may request a meeting regarding such changes with the Fire
Chief.  If after meeting with the Fire Chief, WBVFA continues to be
dissatisfied with such changes, it may request a meeting regarding those
matters with the Town Manager. Any such request shall be in writing, shall
specifically state the concerns of WBVFA and shall be signed by the President
of WBVFA. The request shall be presented to the Fire Chief. Upon receipt of a
request in proper form, the Fire Chief will forward such request to the Town
Manager who will set a date and a time for a meeting to consider the concerns
of WBVFA. Such meeting will be attended by town personnel as deemed
appropriate by the Town Manager. Officers of WBVFA may attend but the meeting
will not be open to the general membership of WBVFA. The Town Manager shall
give a written response to the concerns of WBVFA following such meeting and
the Manager's decision in such matter shall be final.



   (C)   WBVFA may use the fire station as a meeting place subject to
rules and regulations and scheduling as approved by the Fire Chief.



   (D)   Because of the relationship between the Fire Department and
WBVFA, there is the possibility that the general public may confuse the two
organizations.  The volunteer members of the Fire Department have
historically solicited funds from members of the community.  The town does
not intend to restrict the ability of WBVFA to solicit funds on its own, but
all such solicitations must clearly state that they are being made on behalf
of WBVFA and no town funds may be used in conjunction with such solicitation
efforts.



   (E)   (1)   All equipment used by volunteer and paid members of
the Fire Department shall be owned by the town. The town acknowledges that it
has been the policy of the volunteer members of the Fire Department to
purchase equipment for use by members of the Fire Department. The town
acknowledges the debt that it owes to the volunteer Fire Department members
for their efforts in obtaining equipment for the Fire Department. However, 
in order to eliminate any question regarding ownership of property used by
members of the Fire Department, it is hereby declared that all such property
is property of the town.



      (2)   All equipment purchased by WBVFA for use by the Fire
Department shall be formally offered to the town and accepted by the Board of
Aldermen. The Town Manager is hereby authorized to act as agent for the Board
of Aldermen and to accept equipment purchased by WBVFA for use by the Fire
Department and having a value of $500 or less.



   (F)   In the event WBVFA chooses to use some of its funds raised
through solicitation or otherwise for the purpose of providing training for
members of the Fire Department, both paid and volunteer, such funds shall
only be utilized in a manner as approved by the Fire Chief.  In no event
shall there be a co-mingling of town funds with funds of WBVFA.



   (G)   The Town Manager is ultimately responsible for the operation
of the Fire Department in a manner consistent with direction given by the
Board of Aldermen. All members of the Fire Department, both paid and
volunteer, shall be subject to rules and regulations regarding operation of
the Fire Department as promulgated by the Town Manager and the Fire Chief.



(Ord. 1240, passed 8-25-94)



PLANNING BOARD



§ 32.10  CREATION.



   Pursuant to state law, G.S. § 160A-361, a Planning Board for the town
is hereby created.



('72 Code, § 2-12)  (Ord., passed 3-20-69)



§ 32.11  COMPOSITION; FILLING VACANCIES.



   The Planning Board shall consist of seven members, all of whom shall be
citizens of the town and appointed by the Board of Aldermen.  All members
shall be appointed for two-year terms or until a successor is appointed. 
Members' terms shall run from February 1 through January 31.  No member of
the Planning Board shall serve more than three consecutive terms.  Vacancies
occurring for reasons other than expiration of terms shall be filled as they
occur by the Board of Aldermen for the period of the unexpired term.



('72 Code, § 2-13)  (Ord., passed 3-20-69; Am. Ord., passed 6-27-74; Am.
Ord. 1170, passed 3-12-92; Am. Ord. 1329, passed 3-11-99; Am. Ord. 1654,
passed 4-14-11)



§ 32.12  ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS; RECORDS.



   (A)   There shall be a Chairman and Vice Chairman elected annually
by the Board members at the regular meeting in February.  The Board shall
adopt Rules of Procedure which shall  be  effective  following approval by
the Board of Aldermen.  The Board shall keep minutes of meetings, records of
the members' attendance and resolutions, discussions, findings and
recommendations, all of which minutes and such records shall be furnished to
the Board of Aldermen.  The records shall be considered public records. 
The Board shall hold at least one meeting each month and all meetings shall
be open to the public and subject to the provisions of G.S. Chapter 143,
Article 33C regarding open meetings.



   (B)   The Board of Aldermen shall have the authority to remove any
member who misses three consecutive regular meetings or more than four total
meetings during his or her membership on the Planning Board.  It shall be
the responsibility of the Chairman of the Planning Board to advise the Board
of Aldermen of any member who misses three consecutive regular meetings or
more than a total of four meetings.  In the event the Board of Aldermen
removes a member because of his or her failure to comply with the attendance
requirements set forth herein, the Board of Aldermen shall notify the
Chairman of the Planning Board, in writing, that the member has been
removed.  Each member shall notify the Chairman or the Planning staff at
least 48 hours before a regular meeting when an absence is anticipated.



('72 Code, § 2-14)  (Ord., passed 3-20-69; Am. Ord., passed 6-27-74; Am.
Ord. 1170, passed 3-12-92; Am. Ord. 1252, passed 5-25-95)



Statutory reference:



   Meetings open to public, see G.S. § 143-318.10



§ 32.13  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Planning Board shall have the following powers and duties:



   (A)  Studies.  To make careful studies of present conditions and the
probable future development of the town and its environs.  Such studies may
include but are not limited to land use surveys; population studies; economic
base studies; schools, parks, and recreation studies; traffic studies; and
urban renewal studies.



   (B)  Comprehensive plan.  To formulate and maintain a comprehensive
plan of the town and its environs for the purpose of achieving a coordinated,
adjusted, and harmonious development of the municipality which would promote,
in accordance with present and future needs, the safety, morals, order,
convenience, prosperity, and general welfare of its citizens; efficiency and
economy in the process of development; convenience of traffic; safety from
fire and other dangers; adequate light and air; healthful and convenient
distribution of population; provision of adequate open spaces; good civic
design and arrangement; wise and efficient expenditures of public funds;
adequate provision for public utilities; and other matters pertaining to
public requirements.  The comprehensive plan shall consist of a number of
parts which may include but not be limited to the following:  a land use
plan, a major thoroughfare plan, a utilities plan, a plan for economic
development, a recreation plan, a school plan, and a community facilities
plan.



   (C)   Zoning ordinances.  To suggest revisions from time to time to
the existing zoning ordinances and to make other recommendations as the
Planning Board deems appropriate from time to time to the Board of Aldermen
regarding zoning ordinances.



   (D)  Subdivision regulations.  To suggest revisions from time to time
to the existing subdivision regulations and to make other recommendations as
the Planning Board deems appropriate from time to time to the Board of
Aldermen regarding subdivision ordinances.



   (E)  Powers of review.  To review and make recommendations to the
Board of Aldermen upon the extent, location, and design of all public
structures and facilities; on the acquisition and disposal of public
properties; on the opening, abandonment, widening, extension, narrowing, or
other change to streets and other public ways; and on the construction,
extension, expansion, or abandonment of utilities, whether publicly or
privately owned.  However, in the absence of a recommendation from the
Planning Board after the expiration of 30 days from the date on which the
question has been submitted in writing to the Board, the Board of Aldermen
may if it deems wise, take final action.



   (F)  Annual report.  To submit, in April of each year, to the Board
of Aldermen, a report of its activities, for the preceding year.



   (G)   Prior approval by the Board of Aldermen.  In exercising the
powers and duties set forth herein, the Planning Board is authorized to
appoint committees made up in whole or in part of citizens of the town who
are not members of the Planning Board.  Provided, however, that the creation
of the committees and the appointments thereto shall be subject to the prior
approval of the Board of Aldermen.



   (H)    Staff support.  The Town Manager shall be responsible for
appointing staff personnel to support the activities of the Planning Board. 
The Town Manager shall designate those staff members so appointed in writing
and shall provide a copy of the designation to the Planning Board Chairman. 
The Planning Board shall not utilize the services of any staff personnel
other than those so designated without the prior approval of the Town Manager.



('72 Code, § 2-16)  (Ord., passed 3-20-69; Am. Ord. 1170, passed 3-12-92)



Statutory reference:



   Planning Board duties, see G.S. § 160A-361



POLICE DEPARTMENT



§ 32.20  ORGANIZATION.



   The Police Department of the town shall consist of a Chief and as many
police officers as the Board of Aldermen shall from time to time determine
and elect, and as many police officers as the Mayor and Board of Aldermen may
deem necessary to appoint for special purposes.



('72 Code, § 16-l)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to establish, see G.S. § 160A-281



§ 32.21  DUTIES OF CHIEF.



   The Chief of Police shall have control over the Police Department under
the general supervision of  the Town Manager.  The  Chief  shall  keep 
the Town  Manager informed  of the Department's activities and make such
reports as the Town Manager may from time to time require.  He shall perform
other duties as may be required of him by the Board of Aldermen and Town
Manager.



('72 Code, § 16-2)



§ 32.22  DUTIES OF POLICE.



   The Police Department shall carry out all orders of the Board of
Aldermen and Town Manager, shall enforce all laws of the state, all
provisions of this code and other ordinances of the town, and shall at all
times preserve the peace and protect the property and the safety of the
citizens of the town.



('72 Code, § 16-3)



Statutory reference:



   Powers and duties, see G.S. § 160A-285



§ 32.23  TOWN MANAGER TO SUPERVISE.



   The Town Manager shall have general supervision over the Police
Department.



('72 Code, § 16-4)



§ 32.24  UNIFORMS.



   All police officers shall wear uniforms provided by the town and shall
keep such uniforms in a neat and clean condition.  They shall surrender all
uniforms and equipment upon leaving the police service of the town.



('72 Code, § 16-5)



§ 32.25  REQUIREMENTS OF EMPLOYMENT.



   Each person appointed as a police officer shall meet all requirements
established by the North Carolina General Statutes and appropriate state
regulatory agencies.



Statutory reference:



   Oath of office, see G.S. § 160A-284



   State law requirements, see G.S. § 17C-10



§ 32.26  ISSUANCE OF CIVIL PENALTIES.



   Police officers employed by the town shall have the authority to issue
civil penalty citations for all town ordinances made specifically punishable
by civil penalty.  In addition, the Ocean Rescue Director, the Lifeguard
Captain, and any Park Ranger shall have the authority to issue civil penalty
citations for all town ordinances made specifically punishable by civil
penalty.



(Ord., passed 8-10-78; Am. Ord. 1138, passed 3-14-91; Am. Ord. 1475, passed
4-14-05)



§ 32.27  RESERVE POLICE DIVISION.



   (A)   There is established within the Police Department, as a
division thereof, a Reserve Police Division. This Division shall be a
volunteer organization composed of as many members as may from time to time
be determined by the Police Chief and approved by the Town Manager.



   (B)   The Division shall be under the direct control of the Chief of
Police or his or her designee, acting under the general supervision of the
Town Manager. Members of the Division when on active duty shall be subject to
the same chain of command within the Police Department as are regular
officers. Provided further, that members of the Division while on active duty
shall obey the instructions of regular officers in carrying out their duties.
All appointments and removals of members of this Division shall be made at
the discretion of the Chief of Police.



   (C)   The Reserve Police Division shall have no commanding officer,
or any officers other than the Chief of Police or his or her designee and all
members shall bear the rank of Police Officer I. The Chief of Police shall
provide for adequate training and establish policies and procedures
regulating the conduct and performance of members of the Division, and of
candidates for membership.



   (D)   The duties of the Division, subject at all times to the
direction, supervision and control of the Chief of Police or his or her
designee, shall be to assist the regular members of the Police Department in
the enforcement of law and the maintenance of peace and order when called to
active duty by the Chief of Police or his or her designee. The Chief shall,
by order, establish rules and regulations to govern the Division, to fix the
specific duties of its members, and to provide for the maintenance of
discipline. Members of the Division shall obey the instructions of regular
police officers in carrying out their duties. The Chief may prescribe other
duties than those mentioned herein to be performed by the Division, with
approval of the Town Manager.



   (E)  An identification card and other insignia or evidence of identity
as the Chief may prescribe shall be issued to each member of the Division,
who must carry the card and other identification at all times while on duty,
and who must surrender them upon the termination of membership.



   (F)   No member of the Division shall, while on duty, carry or use
any firearm other than a type approved or issued at the direction of the
Chief of Police.



   (G)   No member or members of the Division shall enforce, nor
attempt to enforce, any law, except within the normal jurisdiction of the
town. Reserve Officers will at all times conduct themselves in the same
manner and under the same limitations as regular police officers as described
by North Carolina General Statutes, town ordinances and Police Department
Standard Operating Procedures.



   (H)  While undergoing official training and while performing duties on
behalf of the town pursuant to orders or instructions of the Chief of Police,
members of the Division shall be entitled to benefits under the North
Carolina Workmen's Compensation Act pursuant to G.S. § 160A-282(a).



(Ord. passed 12-7-78; Am. Ord. 1271, passed 5-9-96; Am. Ord. 1416, passed
6-13-02)



Statutory reference:



   Authority to establish, see G.S. § 160A-282



   Oath of office, see G.S. § 160A-284



PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY COMMITTEE



§ 32.35  CREATION; APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.



   There is created the Town Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee
composed of seven citizens of the town.  Each member of the Committee shall
be appointed by the Board of Aldermen.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1298, passed 1-22-98; Am. Ord. 1472, passed
2-24-05; Am. Ord. 1492, passed 1-26-06; Am. Ord. 1646, passed 2-10-11; Am.
Ord. 1668, passed 1-12-12)



Statutory reference:



   Recreation defined, see G.S. § 160A-352



   State policy, see G.S. § 160A-351



§ 32.36  LENGTH OF APPOINTMENT.



   Each member shall be appointed to serve for a two-year term. Members’
terms shall run from February 1 through January 31, or until a successor is
appointed. Members may be appointed for no more than three consecutive terms.
Any person who has previously served as a member of the Board for three
consecutive terms cannot serve a subsequent term until at least one year has
expired since the end of his or her last term.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord., passed



3-13-75; Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92; Am. Ord. 1592, passed 2-26-09)



§ 32.37  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee shall serve as an
advisory body for the Department of Planning and Parks. The Committee shall
recommend policies to the Planning and Parks Director or his or her designee
within its powers and responsibilities as stated in this subchapter. The
Committee shall serve as a liaison between the Planning and Parks Department
and the citizens of the community in parks and recreation matters. The
Committee shall consult with and make recommendations to the Planning and
Parks Department Director or his or her designee in matters affecting parks
and recreation policies, programs, and the acquisition and disposal of lands
and properties related to the total community parks and recreation program,
and to its long-range, projected program for parks and recreation. The
Planning and Parks Director or his or her designee will submit Committee
recommendations to the Town Manager and/or Board of Aldermen for appropriate
action.



   (B)   The Committee shall make recommendations relating to the
acceptance by the town of any grants, gifts, or bequests of any personal or
real property offered or made available for parks and recreational purposes
and which are judged to be of present or possible future use for or to parks
and recreation. Any gift, bequest of money or other property, grant, or
devise of real property or personal property so acquired, shall be held by
the town, used, and finally disposed of in accordance with the terms under
which the grant, gift, or devise is made and accepted.



   (C)   Upon investigating and interpreting the needs of the
community, the Committee shall make recommendations in regard to the
construction and equipping of parks, playgrounds, and recreation centers
necessary or useful to parks and recreation function and programming.



   (D)   The Town Manager shall be responsible for appointing staff
personnel to support the activities of the Parks and Recreation Advisory
Committee. The Town Manager shall designate those staff members so appointed
in writing and shall provide a copy of the designation to the Director of
Planning and Parks. The Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee shall not
utilize the services of any staff personnel other than those so designated
without the prior approval of the Town Manager.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92; Am. Ord. 1592, passed
2-26-09)



Statutory reference:



   General powers, see G.S. § 160A-353



§ 32.38  MEETINGS.



   The Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee meetings shall be held on a
monthly basis as approved by the Board of Aldermen. The Chairman or in his or
her absence, the Vice-Chairman, may request a special meeting of the
Committee at any time. Special meetings may also be requested at any time by
at least five Committee members. Upon approval by the Board of Aldermen,
notice of regular and special meetings shall be given in accordance with G.S.
§ 143-318.9 et seq. A quorum of the Committee shall be in attendance before
action of an official nature can be taken. A majority of the actual
membership of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee, excluding vacant
seats, shall constitute a quorum in accordance with G.S. § 160A-74. A member
who has withdrawn from a meeting without being excused by a majority vote of
the remaining members present shall be counted as present for purposes of
determining whether a quorum is present.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1592, passed 2-26-09; Am. Ord. 1594, passed
4-9-09; Am. Ord. 1646, passed 2-10-11)



§ 32.39  ATTENDANCE.



   The Board of Aldermen shall have the authority to remove any member who
misses three consecutive regular meetings or more than four total meetings
during any two-year term of membership on the Parks and Recreation Advisory
Committee.  It shall be the responsibility of the Chairman of the Parks and
Recreation Advisory Committee to advise the Board of Aldermen of any member
who misses three consecutive regular meetings or more than a total of four
meetings.  In the event the Board of Aldermen removes a member because of
his or her failure to comply with the attendance requirements set forth
herein, the Board of Aldermen shall notify the Chairman of the Parks and
Recreation Advisory Committee in writing that the member has been removed. 
Vacancies occurring for reasons other than expiration of terms shall be
filled by the Board of Aldermen for the period of the unexpired term.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92; Am. Ord. 1592, passed
2-26-09)



§ 32.40  COMPENSATION.



   Committee members shall serve without monetary compensation.  Subject
to the prior approval of the Town Manager and in compliance with existing
policies of the town, members may be reimbursed for travel and subsistence to
professional recreation meetings, conferences and workshops.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92; Am. Ord. 1592, passed
2-26-09)



§ 32.41  OFFICERS.



   There shall be a Chairman and Vice- Chairman of the Parks and
Recreation Advisory Committee. An annual election of the Chairman and
Vice-Chairman shall be held by the Committee members and shall occur at the
regular monthly meeting in February.  Officers shall serve for one year from
election, with eligibility for re-election.  In the event an officer's
appointment to the Committee is terminated, a replacement to this office
shall be elected by the Committee, from its membership, at the meeting
following the termination.  The Planning and Parks Director or his or her
designee shall serve as Secretary of the Committee.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1592, passed 2-26-09)



§ 32.42  OFFICERS' DUTIES.



   (A)  The Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee Chairman shall
preside at all meetings and sign all documents relative to action taken by
the Committee.



   (B)  When the Chairman is absent, the Vice-Chairman shall perform the
duties of the Chairman.  When both the Chairman and Vice-Chairman are
absent, a temporary Chairman shall be selected by those members who are
present.



   (C)   The Secretary shall keep minutes of meetings, records of the
members' attendance and records of discussions, findings and recommendations,
all of which minutes and such records shall be furnished to the Board of
Aldermen.  The records shall be considered public records.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92; Am. Ord. 1592, passed
2-26-09)



§ 32.43  SUB-COMMITTEES.



   (A)   Subject to the prior approval of the Board of Aldermen, in
exercising the powers and duties set forth herein, the Parks and Recreation
Advisory Committee may appoint sub-committees composed only of appointed
members of the Committee.



   (B)   Under certain circumstances the need may arise to create a
sub-committee made up in whole or in part of citizens of the town who are not
members of the Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee.  Formation of such a
sub-committee shall be of a temporary nature to address a specific purpose
and shall not be authorized without approval of the Board of Aldermen. The
actual appointment of sub-committee members who are not already members of
the Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee shall be made by the Board of
Aldermen. The Recreation Advisory Committee may provide recommendations to
the Board of Aldermen pertaining to the selection of non-committee members
for appointment to a special sub-committee.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92; Am. Ord. 1592, passed
2-26-09; Am. Ord. 1646, passed 2-10-11)



§ 32.44  BY-LAWS.



   The Parks and Recreation Advisory Committee is authorized to adopt
procedures for conducting its meetings and other matters which shall be
incorporated into a set of by-Laws.  Provided, however, that the by-Laws
shall not be effective until approved by the Board of Aldermen.



(Ord., passed 7-25-74; Am. Ord., passed 3-13-75;Am. Ord. 1179, passed 5-14-92)



HISTORIC LANDMARK COMMISSION



§ 32.46  HISTORIC LANDMARK COMMISSION.



   A Historic Landmark Commission is hereby established in accordance with
the provisions of G.S. § 160A-400.7.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92; Am. Ord. 1222, passed 12-2-93)



§ 32.47  APPOINTMENT AND TENURE OF MEMBERS.



   The Historic Landmark Commission shall be composed of five members
appointed by the Board of Aldermen.  The term of office shall be two
years.  Members shall be appointed for terms of two years as vacancies
occur.  An appointment to fill an unexpired term shall be only for the
remaining portion of that term.  Membership on the Historic Landmark
Commission will be limited to three consecutive terms. Members shall continue
to serve until their successors are appointed.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92; Am. Ord. 1222, passed 12-2-93)



§ 32.48  COMPOSITION.



   All members of the Historic Landmark Commission shall be residents of
the town.  A majority of the members of the Historic Landmark Commission
shall have demonstrated special interest, experience or education in history,
architecture, archeology or related fields.  All members shall serve without
compensation.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92; Am. Ord. 1222, passed 12-2-93)



§ 32.49  ATTENDANCE AT MEETINGS.



   Should a member fail to attend three consecutive regular meetings of
the Commission, and should there be no adequate excuse for the absences, the
Chairman, with the concurrence of a majority of the entire Commission, shall
recommend to the Board of Aldermen that a vacancy be declared and that the
vacant position be filled by the Board of Aldermen.  Absence due to illness,
death or other emergency situations shall not affect the member's status
excepting that of an extreme duration resulting in prolonged absence, whereby
the procedure for replacement of the member as specified in § 32.47 shall be
followed.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92)



§ 32.50  RULES OF PROCEDURE.



   The Historic Landmark Commission shall adopt rules of procedure subject
to approval of such rules by the Board of Aldermen for the conduct of its
business.  The Commission shall keep a record of its members' attendance and
of its resolutions, findings and recommendations and the records shall be of
public record.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92; Am. Ord. 1222, passed 12-2-93)



§ 32.51  MEETINGS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC.



   All meetings of the Commission shall be open to the public and governed
by the provisions of G.S. Ch. 143, Art. 33C.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92)



§ 32.52  AUTHORITY AND POWER.



   The Historic Landmark Commission is authorized to discharge and conduct
its duties and responsibilities in accordance with the provisions of this
chapter and as specified in G.S. Ch. 160A, Art. 19, Part 3C.  Provided, that
pending establishment by the Board of Aldermen of a historic district either
as a separate use district classification under the town's zoning ordinance
or as districts which overlay other zoning districts or designation of one or
more historic landmarks in accordance with G.S. § 160A-400.5, the Commission
shall limit its activities to the following:



   (A)   Conduct an investigation of and prepare a report describing
the boundaries of any proposed historic districts within the town and
describing the significance of the buildings, structures, features, sites or
surroundings included in the proposed district, such investigation and report
to be in accordance with the provisions of G.S. § 160A-400.4;



   (B)   Upon conclusion of the investigation and report, the
Commission shall forward the report to the Department of Cultural Resources
acting through the State Historic Preservation Officer or his or her designee
for analysis and recommendations in accordance with the provisions of G.S. §
160A-400.4;



   (C)   Following action on the report by the Department of Cultural
Resources as specified above, the Commission shall forward the report to the
Town's Planning Board for its review and recommendation.  The Planning Board
shall make its recommendations upon conclusion of a review of the report to
the Board of Aldermen;



   (D)   Upon receipt of the recommendations of the Planning Board, the
Board of Aldermen shall take such action as it deems appropriate.  Before
taking any action on the recommendations, the Board of Aldermen shall hold a
public hearing for the purpose of soliciting input from the public concerning
the recommendations;



   (E)   The Commission is authorized to undertake other activities as
specified in G.S. Ch. 160A, Art. 19, Part 3C, which are required to be
carried out prior to the establishment by the Board of Aldermen of a historic
district either as a separate use district classification under the town
zoning ordinance or as districts which overlay other zoning districts or
designation of one or more historic landmarks in accordance with G.S. §
160A-400.5.



   (F)   From and after the designation of a landmark, no exterior
portion of any building or other structure (including masonry walls, fences,
light fixtures, steps and pavement, or other appurtenant features) nor
above-ground utility structures nor any type of outdoor advertising sign
shall be erected, altered, restored, moved, or demolished on such landmark
until after an application for a Certificate of Appropriateness as to
exterior features has been submitted to and approved by the Historic Landmark
Commission.  A Certificate of Appropriateness under the provisions of this
section shall be required whether or not a building permit is required, but,
in all instances where such a permit is required, the Certificate of
Appropriateness shall be issued prior to the issuance of a building permit.



(Ord. 1198, passed 9-10-92; Am. Ord. 1213, passed 6-10-93; Am. Ord. 1222,
passed 12-2-93)



§ 32.53  DESIGN REVIEW PROCESS FOR CERTIFICATE OF APPROPRIATENESS.



   Applications for Certificate of Appropriateness shall be subject to
review based upon the design principles and guidelines then in effect and as
have been adopted by the Historic Landmark Commission and approved by
resolution of the Board of Aldermen.



(Ord. 1213, passed 6-10-93; Am. Ord. 1222, passed 12-2-93)



MARKETING ADVISORY COMMITTEE



§ 32.55  CREATION AND PURPOSE.



   Pursuant to G.S. § 160A-146, the Marketing Advisory Committee of the
town was created for the purpose of providing advice to the Board of Aldermen
and the New Hanover County Tourism Development Authority relating to the
tourism industry in the town.



(Ord. 1504, passed 3-23-06; Am. Ord. 1643, passed 11-18-10)



§ 32.56  COMPOSITION AND APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS.



   The Marketing Advisory Committee shall consist of nine voting members
and two non-voting members. All voting members shall be appointed by the
Board of Aldermen and shall be citizens of the town or representatives from
the town’s business community, including but not limited to small business,
real estate, and the resort/lodging industry within the town.  One
non-voting member shall be the town’s non-governmental representative to
the New Hanover County Tourism Development Authority (TDA); the other
non-voting member shall be a member of the Board of Aldermen. The non- voting
members shall be considered alternate members with full authority to vote on
all matters in those cases where such alternates are necessary to satisfy a
quorum for a meeting. All voting members, except as otherwise provided
herein, shall be appointed for two-year terms or until a successor is
appointed. Terms shall run from July 1 to June 30. The terms of those members
appointed to replace members whose terms expire January 2016 shall expire
June 30, 2018. The terms of current members expiring January 2017 shall
expire June 30, 2017. The initial terms of the two new members added by Ord.
1754 shall begin on February 1, 2016 and shall expire on June 30, 2017.
Thereafter, the terms of such members shall be for two years. The term of the
non-voting member who is the town’s non- governmental representative to the
TDA shall be as dictated by the membership rules applicable to TDA members.
The term of the non-voting member who is a member of the Board of Aldermen
shall be February 1 to January 31.  No member of the Marketing Advisory
Committee shall serve more than three consecutive terms.  Vacancies
occurring for reasons other than expiration of a term shall be filled as they
occur by the Board of Aldermen for the period of the unexpired term.



(Ord. 1504, passed 3-23-06; Am. Ord. 1617, passed 2-11-10; Am. Ord. 1643,
passed 11-18-10; Am. Ord. 1752, passed 11-12-15; Am. Ord. 1754, passed
12-10-15)



§ 32.57  ORGANIZATION; MEETINGS; RECORDS.



   (A)   There shall be a Chairman, Vice Chairman, and Secretary
elected annually by the Marketing Advisory Committee members at the regular
meeting in February. The Committee shall adopt rules of procedure for the
conduct of its business that shall be effective following approval by the
Board of Aldermen.  Subsequent changes to the rules of procedure shall also
be subject to approval by the Board of Aldermen.  The Committee shall keep
minutes of the meetings and records of the members' attendance, discussions,
and recommendations, all of which minutes and such records shall be furnished
to the Board of Aldermen.  The records shall be considered public records.



   (B)   The Marketing Advisory Committee Chairman shall preside at all
meetings and sign all documents relative to action taken by the Committee. 
When the Chairman is absent, the Vice-Chairman shall perform the duties of
the Chairman.  When both the Chairman and Vice-Chairman are absent, a
temporary Chairman shall be selected by those members who are present.



   (C)   The Marketing Advisory Committee shall hold at least one
meeting each month. The Committee's regular meeting schedule shall be
approved by the Board of Aldermen. The Chairman, or in his or her absence the
Vice-Chairman, may call a special meeting of the Marketing Advisory Committee
at any time.  Notice of special meetings and changes to the regular meeting
schedule shall be given in accordance with G.S. § 143-318.9 et seq. All
meetings shall be open to the public and subject to the provisions of G.S.
Ch. 143, Article 33C, regarding open meetings. A quorum of the Marketing
Advisory Committee shall be in attendance before action of an official nature
can be taken.



   (D)   Routine business shall include issues pertinent to the
successful marketing of the community in relation to tourism as well as a
review of applications being submitted from the Board of Aldermen for funding
projects, programs, or equipment supporting the community's efforts to
attract and support the tourism industry.



   (E)   The Board of Aldermen shall have the authority to remove any
member who misses three consecutive regular meetings or more than four total
meetings in a one-year period.  It shall be the responsibility of the
Chairman of the Committee to advise the Board of Aldermen of any member who
misses three consecutive regular meetings or more than a total of four
meetings in a one-year period.  Absences due to sickness, death, or other
emergencies of a like nature shall be regarded as approved absences and shall
not affect the member's status on the Committee.  However, in the event of a
long illness, or other such cause for prolonged absences, the Chairman of the
Marketing Advisory Committee shall advise the Board of Aldermen of the
situation, and the Board of Aldermen may remove the member.  In the event
the Board of Aldermen removes a member because of his or her failure to
comply with the attendance requirements set forth herein, the Board of
Aldermen shall notify the Chairman of the Committee, in writing, that the
member has been removed.  Each member shall notify the Chairman,
Vice-Chairman, or Secretary at least 48 hours before a regular meeting when
an absence is anticipated.



   (F)   Subject to prior approval by the Board of Aldermen, the
Marketing Advisory Committee may appoint sub-committees composed exclusively
of members of the Marketing Advisory Committee. The role and duration of each
sub-committee must be clearly defined and approved by the Board of Aldermen.
It is the responsibility of the Marketing Advisory Committee Chairman to
insure that all appointed members of the Marketing Advisory Committee be
fully informed of actions and decisions made by each sub-committee.



(Ord. 1504, passed 3-23-06; Am. Ord. 1643, passed 11-18-10)



§ 32.58  RESPONSIBILITY, POWERS, AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Marketing Advisory Committee shall work in concert with
the Board of Aldermen, the TDA, and the Cape Fear Coast Convention and
Visitors Bureau (CFCCVB) to develop programs and initiatives to promote the
tourism industry in the town.



   (B)   Upon approval by the Board of Aldermen, the Marketing Advisory
Committee shall provide annual marketing recommendations to the CFCCVB for
inclusion in the annual county-wide marketing plan.



   (C)   The Marketing Advisory Committee shall function in an advisory
capacity to the Board of Aldermen and shall meet from time to time with the
Board of Aldermen to discuss issues relative to marketing and tourism.



   (D)   The Marketing Advisory Committee shall be provided the
opportunity to review and comment on program funding requests that have been
prepared and approved by the Board of Aldermen prior to submission to the TDA
for consideration.



   (E)   The Marketing Advisory Committee shall work closely with local
non-governmental organizations and the private sector to promote tourism that
will benefit the community.



   (F)   Neither the Marketing Advisory Committee nor any subcommittee
of the Marketing Advisory Committee is empowered to obligate municipal funds,
enter into contracts on behalf of the town, or implement town policy without
the express approval of the Board of Aldermen.



(Ord. 1504, passed 3-23-06; Am. Ord. 1643, passed 11-18-10)



§ 32.59  COMPENSATION.



   Marketing Advisory Committee members shall serve without monetary
compensation.



(Ord. 1504, passed 3-23-06; Am. Ord. 1643, passed 11-18-10)

§ 33.02  PURCHASES BY TOWN EMPLOYEES.



   (A)   Before any order shall be given for items to be paid by the
town or any purchase made by any town employees, a purchase order must first
be obtained from the Finance Officer if the amount of purchase exceeds $500.



   (B)   The Finance Officer may issue the purchase order only when
there are sufficient funds for the purchase and in accordance with the annual
budget as allocated by the Board of Aldermen in the annual budget ordinance.



   (C)   Any town employee purchasing goods exceeding $500 without a
purchase order from the Finance Officer will be held responsible for the cost
of same.



   (D)   The Finance Officer may change the amount necessary for a
purchase order as deemed necessary, provided that this action and amount are
reported to the Board of Aldermen at its next meeting.



('72 Code, § 7-2)  (Am. Ord. 1250, passed 5-18-95; Am. Ord. 1293, passed
9-11-97; Am. Ord. 1721, passed 1-23-14)



§ 33.03  LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS SPECIAL SEPARATION ALLOWANCE TRUST FUND.



   (A)  There is established on the books of the town a trust fund to be
known as the Law Enforcement Officers' Special Separation Allowance Trust
Fund. 



   (B)   The purpose of this trust fund is to receive monies
appropriated by the Board of Aldermen to fund the law enforcement officers'
special separation allowance benefit as required by G.S. § 143-166.42 and to
be a source of payment of special monthly separation allowances to former law
enforcement officers who have retired from employment with the town and who
meet the qualifying requirements of G.S. § 143-166.41 for receipt of
payments of the special separation allowance.



   (C)   The Board of Aldermen shall appropriate monies to the trust
fund as needed to assure that sufficient assets will exist and remain
available to pay future benefits when due.  The Town Manager shall obtain
actuarial evaluations of the status of the trust fund as necessary to assure
adequate appropriations to the trust fund to maintain its actuarial soundness.



   (D)   The Finance Officer shall be and hereby is directed to invest
the monies in the trust fund in deposits and securities eligible for
investment of local funds under state law, until such time as the monies are
needed for disbursement.



(Ord. 1132, passed 1-10-91)



Statutory reference:



   Investment of funds, see G.S. § 159-30



   Local Fiscal Assistance Act, see G.S. § 159, Article 3



   Selection of depository, see G.S. § 159-31



§ 33.04  DISBURSEMENT OF FUNDS.



   (A)  In accordance with the Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control
Act, no bill or claim against the town may be paid unless it has been
approved by the officer or employee responsible for the function or agency to
which the expense is charged.  No check or draft of the town shall be valid
unless it bears on its face the certificate of the Finance Officer as
follows:  "This disbursement has been approved as required by the Local
Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act."



   (B)   No contract, agreement, or purchase order shall be valid
unless it bears the Finance Officer's certificate as follows:  "This
instrument has been pre-audited in the manner required by the Local
Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act."



(Am. Ord. 1250, passed 5-18-95)



Statutory reference:



   Duties of Finance Officer, see  G.S. § 159-2



   Local Government Budget and Fiscal Control Act, see G.S. § 159,
Article 3



   Pre-audit of disbursements, see G.S. § 159-28



§ 33.05  COUNTER-SIGNATURES ON ALL DRAFTS.



   All checks and drafts issued by the town, regardless of amount, must be
signed by the Finance Officer, Town Manager, or Mayor.



(Am. Ord. 1250, passed 5-18-95)



Statutory reference:



   Dual signatures on checks, see G.S. § 159-25



§ 33.06  CAPITAL RESERVE FUND.



   (A)   Pursuant to the authority granted by G.S. § 160-425, there is
hereby created and established a Capital Reserve Fund to be maintained in
addition to all other funds now authorized by law.



   (B)   Moneys appropriated and paid into the Capital Reserve Fund
shall be expended only for those purposes as set out in G.S. § 160.432(1),
(2), (4), (5), (7), and (9).



      (1)   All of the foregoing purposes in division (B) above
declared to be necessary expenses and the cost thereof shall be deemed to
include land, easements, rights in land, water rights, contract rights,
franchises, and equipment used or useful in connection with the said purposes.



      (2)   All money deposited in accordance with the provisions of
this section shall be secured as provided by G.S. § 159-28 of the Local
Government Act.



   (C)   Moneys appropriated and paid into the Capital Reserve Fund may
be invested from time to time as prescribed by G.S. § 160-431 and 159-28.1.



(Ord., passed 7-27-72)



Statutory reference:



   The statutes cited in this section have been repealed and/or
replaced.  For current provisions regarding capital reserve funds, see G.S.
§§159-18 through 159.22



§ 33.07  BAD CHECKS PRESENTED TO THE TOWN.



   When the payor bank of any uncertified check tendered to the town in
payment of any obligation due to the town shall refuse payment upon such
check, and such check shall be returned to the town, a penalty of $25 shall
be imposed.  The penalty shall not be waived or diminished and shall be in
addition to other charges or penalties provided for by law.



(Ord. 1106, passed 11-2-89; Am. Ord. 1158, passed 10-10-91; Am. Ord. 1377,
passed 3-22-01)



§ 33.08  CASH MANAGEMENT POLICY.



   There shall be a Board of Aldermen approved cash management policy that
outlines the town's financial and investment practices.  The policy may be
amended from time to time by the Board of Aldermen.



(Ord. 1250, passed 5-18-95)
