    Authority to fix rates, see G.S.§ 160A-314



§ 50.081  REESTABLISHMENT OF WATER SERVICE WHICH HAS BEEN TERMINATED FOR
NONPAYMENT.



   The town will reestablish service upon payment by the customer of the
past due balance including all late payment charges and applicable
reconnection fees.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83; Am. Ord. 1036, passed 12-4-86) 



§ 50.082  DISCONNECTION, RECONNECTION AND METER READING FEES.



   (A)   Customers whose service has been terminated for nonpayment and
who pay their past due balances and late payment charges shall pay a
reconnection fee of $50 to cover the cost of reestablishing water service to
the customer.  The town shall reestablish water service within a reasonable
amount of time after notification of payment by Town Hall.



   (B)   Customers who request that their water service be disconnected
shall pay a disconnect fee of $30 during normal business hours and $50 during
non-business hours.  There shall be a reconnect fee of $30 during normal
business hours and $50 during non-business hours. Business hours shall be
based upon Water Division schedule, 7:00 a.m. until 4:00 p.m.



   (C)   Customers who request a meter reading without disconnection,
except for property transfers, shall pay a fee of $10 per reading.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83; Am. Ord. 1036, passed 12-4-86; Am. Ord. 1512, passed
7-13-06; Am. Ord. 1537, passed 6-28-07; Am. Ord. 1683, passed 6-14-12)



§ 50.083  SPECIAL RATES.



   All water received as a special use shall be charged at a rate as set
forth in the fee schedule of § 50.080.  A meter rental fee and installation
or removal fee for the meter shall also be assessed for the special use of
water per application as set forth in the fee schedule of § 50.080.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.084  BILLING; PAYMENT OF ACCOUNTS.



   (A)   The owner of improved property within the town shall be liable
for the payment of all water and sewer services furnished to such premises,
and if the charges are not paid, legal action may be taken to collect these
charges.  All bills for water and sewer services shall be rendered to the
owner.



   (B)   Upon failure of the owner to pay the amount charged for either
water or sewer services within the time set forth on billing, both services
may be discontinued without prejudice to the right of the town to recover for
services rendered before discontinuance, as set forth in divisions (1)
through (4) below, and services shall not be restored until the account is
paid.  These rates shall generally be determined on the basis of water
consumption measured for each customer through a metering device installed,
maintained, and read by the town.



      (1)    It is the policy of the town before terminating utility
service, to give the customer a fair opportunity to avoid termination either
by paying charges due or showing that the charges are in error.  As soon as
possible following the past due date, written notice of delinquency shall be
sent to the customer by first-class mail.



      (2)   Notice.  The notice shall contain the following
information:



         (a)    The amount which must be paid to avoid
termination;



         (b)    The date on which termination will occur, which
must be at least ten days after the mailing date; and



         (c)   A statement that the customer may appear at the
office of the Town Manager or his or her designated representative between
the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on any business day and request an
informal hearing with the Town Manager or his or her designee, for the
purpose of showing error or working out a satisfactory extended payment
arrangement.



      (3)    Certification. The employee responsible for mailing the
notice shall certify the date on which the notice was mailed, on a form or in
a record book or electronic medium designed for that purpose.



      (4)    Termination. If the customer does not make acceptable
payment arrangements and fails to show cause why service should not be
terminated, service may be terminated on or after the date specified in the
notice of termination.  Service may be terminated between the hours of 8:30
a.m. and 400 p.m. on business days from Monday through Thursday only.  If
the customer fails to comply with agreed upon extended payment arrangements,
service may be terminated without further notice.



   (C)   For the purpose of spreading more evenly the capital costs
associated with providing the required amount and quality of water and the
collection and treatment of wastewater, systems service charges shall be made
according to the size of the water meter for each billing period on both
water and sewer.  These charges, for customers both inside and outside the
town limits, shall be as set forth in the fee schedule of § 50.080.



   (D)   Whenever water or sewer service is discontinued for any
reason, a fee shall be charged for such discontinuance. Charges for such
service work shall be determined from time to time by the Board of Aldermen
and charge schedules shall be kept on file in the offices of the Town Clerk
and the Director of Public Works.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



DISCONTINUATION, SUSPENSION OF SERVICE



§ 50.090  PROCEDURE FOR DISCONTINUATION OF SERVICE.



   (A)   The town shall serve a written notice to any person allegedly
violating any provision of this chapter.  The notice shall state the
specific nature of the violation and provide the person not less than ten
days to:



      (1)   Correct the violation; or



      (2)   Inquire regarding the notice, and, if the person feels
he or she is not in violation, or that compliance requires greater than ten
days, request a hearing before the Director of Public Works.  If the person
does not respond within the time prescribed in the notice, the town may
immediately discontinue service to this person upon the expiration of the
prescribed time.  If the user receives notice due to non-payment of a bill,
the town may suspend service, after notice, at the direction of the Town
Clerk.



   (B)   If the person allegedly in violation of a provision of this
chapter requests a hearing before the Director, the Director shall, within
five days of the person’s claims, establish the time and place for the
hearing.  If, as a result of the hearing, the Director determines that the
person is in violation of the provision as alleged in the notice, he or she
shall order the person to correct the condition giving rise to the violation,
and establish a reasonable time for compliance.  If the Director cannot, at
the hearing, determine the existence or extent of the alleged violation, he
or she may order the suspension of services.  In the case of suspension of
services, the person is entitled to request a second hearing following the
period of suspension, and in the event he or she does so, no further action
may be taken by the town until the conclusion of the second hearing.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.091  SUSPENSION OF SERVICE.



   If an industrial user is suspected of discharging wastewater into a
public sanitary sewer which is causing operational problems at the public
wastewater treatment facility, pump station, or public sanitary sewer; the
discharge would be in violation of this chapter; and the user has been issued
a written notice but has denied the alleged violation, the town may require
that the user cease to discharge into a public sanitary sewer, upon a hearing
by the Director of Public Works, for up to 30 days.  The suspension shall be
only for the purpose of clearly determining the operational effect of the
user's discharge; the suspension shall not be made if it will likely endanger
the public health, safety, or welfare or otherwise create a public health or
safety nuisance.  Depending upon the results of the suspension on the
operation of the wastewater treatment facilities, the town may take
appropriate action to either restore service or discontinue further service.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.092  DISCONTINUATION IN PROTECTION OF HEALTH AND WELFARE.



   When any public sanitary sewer user discharges, or threatens to
discharge, any wastewater which is prohibited by this chapter which may cause
a present or imminent and substantial endangerment to the health and welfare
of persons, or is likely to cause the disruption or inhibition of the
operation of the town's treatment facilities, the Director may immediately,
upon written notice or verbal notification to the user, discontinue service
to the user.  In such event, the town shall serve a written notice to the
user after discontinuation of service and shall, where feasible, follow the
procedural requirements of this chapter. If, upon fulfillment of such
requirements, it is determined that no violation has occurred, service to the
user shall be restored at no cost to the user.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



EXTENSION OF SERVICE



§ 50.100  APPLICATION FOR APPROVAL OF EXTENSION.



   (A)   Any property owner who desires water or sanitary sewer service
shall apply in writing to the Board of Aldermen requesting the extension of
water or sanitary sewer service.  No request for the extension of services
shall be considered unless submitted in writing in accordance with the
requirements of this subchapter.



   (B)   The town may require the applicant to submit as part of the
written application such information, plans, or other data to determine
adequately if the requirements of this subchapter shall be met.



   (C)   When application is made for water and sewer extensions to
serve an area or development project that is planned as part of a larger
project or subdivision, all of which is not to be developed at the time
application is made, the owner shall submit plans in sufficient detail to
determine the size and type of facilities necessary to serve the entire
development or subdivision when completed.



   (D)   No extension to the water or sanitary sewer system of the town
shall be made and no application shall be approved except in accordance with
the requirements of this subchapter.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.101  GENERAL EXTENSION REQUIREMENTS.



   All extensions of either water or sanitary sewer service shall be
governed by the size of water lines and sanitary sewer lines to be installed
and the other required system facilities shall be determined by the Town
Manager or his designee in accordance with recognized standards and accepted
engineering practices and design.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83; Am. Ord. 1536, passed 6-14-07)



§ 50.102  GENERAL APPROVAL REQUIREMENTS.



   All water and sewer lines and appurtenances shall be designed by a
licensed registered architect or engineer and shall bear his seal.  Proposed
plans shall be submitted to the Director of Public Works in the amount of
seven copies. The plans shall be reviewed by the Director and all town
department heads, who shall submit their comments to the Director.  The
Director shall then, in consultation with the Water and Sewer Division
Superintendent, submit a report to the Board of Aldermen within 30 days of
receipt of the plans.  Any department head who does not comment within ten
working days, shall be considered to have no adverse comment.  Such
extensions, if approved, shall be paid for and the total cost borne by the
property owner.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.103  SPECIFICATIONS FOR EXTENSION; OWNERSHIP.



   (A)   Any water or sanitary sewer mains extended under the
provisions of this subchapter shall be installed and constructed in
accordance with the approved plans, specifications, and other requirements of
the town.  All facilities installed, whether within or outside the town,
shall become the property of the town and shall be under its jurisdiction and
control for all purposes at the time the facilities are connected to the town
system.



   (B)   When required, the property owner shall grant to the town
those utility easements the town may require.  In addition, a deed to the
town for water or sewer facilities installed which are located outside the
town, the cost of which is borne by individual property owners, shall be
executed prior to the time any extension provided for in this subchapter is
connected to the town system.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.104  ADDITIONAL SUBDIVISION IMPROVEMENT MAY BE REQUIRED.



   The Board of Aldermen may, at its discretion, as a condition under
which water or sewer service shall be extended, require the owner of a
proposed subdivision to enter into an agreement to improve the proposed
streets therein at his own expense and in accordance with the provisions of
this code and other ordinances governing the acceptance of public streets for
the town.  If required, this section shall apply to subdivisions which are
located either within or outside the town limits.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.105  APPROVED SUBDIVISION OR DEVELOPED PROPERTY.



   When an application is received requesting the extension of water or
sanitary sewer service to serve property within the town which is developed
or has been previously approved as a subdivision, or where streets have
previously been dedicated and accepted by the town, and where such area is
not part of a new unapproved subdivision, the Director of Public Works or
other person designated by the Board of Aldermen shall estimate the cost of
the project and present the application for such extension, the estimated
cost, and other required information to the Board for its consideration.  If
the application is approved by the Board, and subject to the availability of
funds, the town shall install the extensions which have been approved.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.106  APPROVED EXTENSION PROJECT; ASSESSMENT OF COSTS.



   (A)   All costs associated with any extension of water or sanitary
sewer service, regardless of the length of such extension, shall be paid in
full by the property owner benefitted by such extension.



   (B)   Before undertaking any extension of water or sewer service,
the affected property owner shall provide the town with an estimate of the
cost of such work prepared by a licensed engineer.



   (C)   The Town Manager or his designee shall determine whether the
improvements shall be installed by the town or by the property owner. If such
improvements are installed by the property owner, no work shall be undertaken
until all necessary permits are acquired by the property owner and plans and
specifications acceptable to the town describing the work to be undertaken
have been approved by the town. All work carried out by the property owner
shall be performed by a licensed utility contractor.



   (D)   If such improvements are installed by the town, no work shall
be undertaken until the property owner has deposited with the town a sum
equal to the estimated cost of installation (as approved by the town in its
sole discretion) plus the amount necessary to reimburse the town for the cost
of its services associated with the extension of services.



   (E)   Upon completion of the project, if the cost of extension of
such service, to include the town's cost, exceeds the deposit made by the
property owner, the property owner shall, within ten days of receipt of
written notice from the town, pay the town the difference between its deposit
and the final cost. If the cost of the project, to include the town's fees,
are less than the amount deposited by the property owner, the town shall
within ten days of a determination of the final cost remit any unused balance
to the property owner.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83; Am. Ord. 1536, passed 6-14-07)



Statutory reference:



   Power to assess, see G.S. § 160A-216



§ 50.107  PROPOSED DEVELOPMENT OR UNAPPROVED SUBDIVISION.



   When an application is received requesting the extension of water or
sanitary sewer service to a proposed development or subdivision within the
town which has not been approved by the Board of Aldermen, the Director of
Public Works or other person designated by the Board shall estimate the cost
of the project and present the application for the extension, the estimated
cost, and other required information to the Board for consideration.  If the
application is approved, and subject to the approval of the development or
subdivision by the town, the town shall install the extension under the
conditions set out in this chapter.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.108  FINANCING OF EXTENSION WITHIN TOWN LIMITS.



   (A)   Prior to the beginning of any construction, the property owner
shall advance to the town funds in an amount equal to the total estimated
cost of the proposed extension.



   (B)   Upon receipt of such funds, a written contract shall be
entered into by and between the town and the property owner under which the
town shall use such funds upon the following terms and conditions:



      (1)   The funds shall be deposited in a special account of the
town for which a separate accounting will be made.



      (2)   At the time construction of the extension is completed
and the total cost thereof is determined, if the amount deposited exceeds the
total cost, that portion in excess of the amount deposited will be refunded
to the owner without interest.  If the amount deposited is less than the
total cost, the owner shall pay such additional amount to the town, and this
condition shall be a part of the written contract.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



Cross-reference:



   Financing extensions outside town limits, see § 50.112



§ 50.109  SURETY BOND; REFUND OR REIMBURSEMENT OF FUNDS.



   (A)   In lieu of depositing funds, the owner may provide a surety
bond or some other form of security that will insure payment to the town of
his proportionate share of the cost of extension.



   (B)   No refund or reimbursement of funds shall be made to the owner
who pays the total cost of extension except as provided for in § 50.108.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.110  EXCEPTIONS FROM FOLLOWING EXTENSION PROCEDURE AUTHORIZED.



   Nothing in this chapter shall prevent the Board of Aldermen from
extending water or sanitary sewer mains within the town on its own motion
without receipt of an application from property owners, and from assessing
the cost of such an extension in accordance with this chapter when, in the
opinion of the Board, the general public interest demands such an extension
of service.  The Board may decline to assess the cost of such an extension
and pay for the same from town funds.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.111  EXTENSION OUTSIDE TOWN; APPLICATION.



   All applications for water and sewer extensions outside the corporate
limits shall be made in the same manner and under the same requirements as
provided for in this chapter.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



Statutory reference:



    Special rates for water and sewer, see G.S. § 160A-58.5



§ 50.112  FINANCING OF EXTENSION OUTSIDE TOWN LIMITS.



   If an application is approved by the Board of Aldermen the owner shall
pay for the entire cost of the extension.  However, the town may participate
to the extent agreed upon by the Board in the cost of larger mains which are
in excess of the size of mains required to serve the project.  No
reimbursement shall be made upon annexation and all water and sewer lines
connected to the town system and located outside the town shall become the
property of the town at the time such facilities are connected.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



Cross-reference:



   Financing extensions within town limits, see § 50.108



§ 50.113  DEPOSIT OF FUNDS; CONTRACT FOR EXTENSION OUTSIDE TOWN LIMITS.



   Prior to the beginning of any construction, the owner shall deposit
with the town funds in an amount equal to the total estimated cost of such
extension. Upon receipt of such funds a written contract shall be entered
into by and between the town and the property owner in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter.  The contract shall provide that in the event
the amount of the total funds deposited exceeds the amount of the extension
cost when completed, that portion in excess of the total cost shall be
refunded to the owner without interest. The contract shall also provide that
if the amount deposited is less than the total cost, the owner shall pay the
additional amount to the town.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.114  SURETY BOND OR PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION FOR EXTENSION OUTSIDE TOWN
LIMITS.



   In lieu of depositing funds the owner may execute a surety bond
guaranteeing payment for such extension or the owner may have such extension
work performed under private contract with the approval of the Board of
Aldermen.  However, the work shall be performed in accordance with all
construction requirements of the town and subject to inspection and approval
of the town.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.115  ANNEXATION.



   If the property for which an application has been made for water and
sewer service is contiguous to the town, the owner of such property agrees to
annexation, and if the property is annexed to the town, an extension may be
made to such property and the cost thereof financed in accordance with the
requirements of this chapter.



(Ord., passed 7-28-83)



§ 50.116  CUTOFF OF PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY AT PIERS.



   No pier shall be provided with public water unless it has installed by
the owner of such pier a device for cutting off the public water supply to
such pier.  Such cutoff device shall be installed on property owned by the
pier owner and shall be installed in accordance with regulations promulgated
by the Department of Public Works.  The owner of any pier having a supply of
public water for which no cutoff device currently exists shall comply with
the provisions of this section on or before April 1, 1998.  Any owner
failing to comply with the provisions of this section shall have the public
water supply to that owner's pier terminated.



(Ord. 1292, passed 7-31-97)



WATER SUPPLY SHORTAGE



§ 50.120  ISSUANCE OF WATER SHORTAGE PROCLAMATION.



   In the event of an existing or threatening state of emergency
endangering the safety, health or welfare of the people of the town, or
threatening damage or destruction of property, arising from the shortage or
threatened shortage of water, the Town Manager or the Public Works Director
is hereby authorized and empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring
the existence of such state of emergency, and to define and impose such
appropriate prohibitions and restrictions resulting from the water shortage
applicable to all persons within the jurisdiction of the town in order to
meet the requirements of the predetermined state of emergency.



(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.121  CONDITIONS DEEMED EMERGENCY.



   A state of emergency shall be deemed to exist whenever the availability
and supply of water is critical due to a mechanical malfunction or breakdown
of the town's pumps or distribution system, a rapid drawdown of the water
supply {aquifer}, salt water intrusion, or specific triggers (as defined in
the Water Shortage Response Plan) would require the reduction of water usage
in order to protect the availability of water for human consumption, for
firefighting purposes and other protection of lives and property, and the
conservation of water is necessary in order to protect lives, safety and
property within the town.



(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.122  RESTRICTIONS, LIMITATIONS IMPOSED.



   (A)   The Town Manager or Public Works Director is hereby authorized
and empowered to issue a public proclamation declaring to all persons the
existence of such state of emergency.



   (B)   Such proclamation may specify the authorized uses of water
within the town, and may place limitations, prohibitions and restrictions
upon the usage of water for residential, business, commercial, industrial and
municipal uses. Such proclamation may limit the use of water for non-crucial
uses such as the watering of lawns, washing of automobiles, and similar
activities and may be expanded thereafter to include other activities.
Specifically exempted from restrictions are those activities by the Public
Works Department deemed necessary to maintain water quality to necessary
standards. The proclamation will use predetermined stages of water
restrictions found in § 50.127.



(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.123  PROCLAMATION, RESTRICTIONS, AND THE LIKE SHALL BE WRITTEN.



   Upon the declaration of a proclaimed state of emergency arising from
the availability or shortage of water, such proclamation and all
restrictions, prohibitions, and limitations on the use of water shall be in
writing and duly signed by the Town Manager or the Public Works Director. All
restrictions, prohibitions, and limitations upon the use of water during the
proclaimed state of emergency shall be in writing and specifically described
and identified so that the citizens and the residents of the town shall have
available the specific activities authorized and the specific activities
prohibited.



(ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.124  END OF EMERGENCY; LIFTING OR MODIFICATION OF RESTRICTIONS.



   The Town Manager or Public Works Director shall proclaim the end of
such state of emergency and shall have the authority to modify, lift or
suspend any restrictions, limitations or prohibitions stated in such
proclamation of emergency as soon as the circumstances warrant.



(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)

(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.126  NON-ESSENTIAL WATER USAGE ND IRRIGATION CONTROL.



   For the purposes of controlling non-essential (irrigation) water usage,
the Town of Wrightsville Beach shall be divided into the following zones.



   (A)   Zone 1. The north end of Wrightsville Island beginning at the
center of Salisbury Street (East and West) and continuing north past 2700 N
Lumina; this shall include all properties north of the aforementioned
dividing line.



   (B)   Zone 2. The south end of Wrightsville Island beginning at the
center of Stone Street to the center of the Causeway bridge on Wrightsville
Island and continuing south to Jack Parker Blvd; this shall include all
properties south of the aforementioned dividing line.



   (C)   Zone 3. The center of Wrightsville Beach beginning at the
center of Salisbury Street (East and West) and continuing south to the center
of Stone Street to the center of the Causeway bridge on Wrightsville Island;
this shall include all properties between the dividing lines for Zones 1 and
2 and all of Harbor Island and the annexed areas on the west side of the
Intracoastal Waterway.



(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.127  WATER SHORTAGE RESPONSE.



   (A)   STAGE 1: Voluntary Reductions. All water users will be asked
to reduce their normal water use by 5%. Customer education and outreach
programs will encourage water conservation and efficiency measures including:
irrigating landscapes a maximum of one inch per week; preventing water waste,
runoff and watering impervious surfaces; watering plants deeply to encourage
root growth; washing only full loads in clothes and dishwashers; using
spring-loaded nozzles on garden hoses; and identifying and repairing all
water leaks.



   (B)   STAGE 2: Mandatory Reductions I. All customers are expected to
reduce their water use by 10% in comparison to their previous month's water
usage/or monthly average of previous water bills. In addition to continuing
to encourage all voluntary reduction actions, the following restrictions
apply: outdoor use of drinking water for washing impervious surfaces is
prohibited; all testing and training purposes requiring drinking water (e.g.
fire protection) will be limited; watering of lawns, grass, shrubbery, trees,
flowers or vegetable gardens shall be limited to an inch per week as follows:



      (1)   Zone 1 - Sunday and Wednesday between the hours of 12:00
a.m. and 8:00 a.m.



      (2)   Zone 2 - Monday and Thursday between the hours of 12:00
a.m. and 8:00 a.m.



      (3)   Zone 3 - Tuesday and Friday between the hours of 12:00
a.m. and 8:00 a.m.



      (4)   There shall be no watering on Saturday.



   (C)   STAGE 3: Mandatory Reductions II. Customers must continue
actions from all previous stages and further reduce water use by 20% compared
to their previous month's water usage/or monthly average of previous water
bills; watering of lawns, grass, shrubbery, trees, flowers or vegetable
gardens shall be limited to a half inch per week as follows:



      (1)   Zone 1 - Wednesday between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and
8:00 a.m.



      (2)   Zone 2 - Monday between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 8:00
a.m.



      (3)   Zone 3 - Tuesday between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and
8:00 a.m.



      (4)   There shall be no watering on Thursday,  Friday, 
Saturday and Sunday.



   (D)   STAGE 4: Emergency Reductions. Customers must continue all
actions from previous stages and further reduce their water use by 25%
compared to their previous month's water usage/or monthly average of previous
water bills. A ban on all use of drinking water except to protect public
health and safety is implemented.



   (E)   STAGE 5: Water Rationing. Is to provide drinking water to
protect public health. All customers are only permitted to use water at the
minimum required for public health protection. Firefighting is the only
allowable outdoor water use.



(Ord. 1644, passed 12-9-10)



§ 50.128  WATER SHORTAGE RESPONSE ENFORCEMENT.



   (A)   The provisions of the water shortage response plan will be
enforced by Town of Wrightsville Beach Utility Department and police
personnel. Violators may be reported to the town's dedicated water emergency
hotline or the e-mail contact listed on the town's website through the online
work order system; entries may remain anonymous. Citations are assessed
according to the following schedule depending on the number of prior
violations and current level of water shortage.

   (B)   Drought surcharge rates, if applicable, are effective in
